utterances: Thank you.
And that raises a point.
How much beyond that hall in Denver, Farai Chideya, do you think that Senator Clinton's remarks extended?
All the way to the moon.
(Soundbite of laughter)

I mean, people are watching this so closely and I do want to bring up something else that really struck me, which is that essentially two paragraphs - not that a speech has paragraphs, but a transcription does.
Two paragraphs before the Harriet Tubman bit of the speech, she said, my mother was born before women could vote.
My daughter got to vote for her mother for president.
This is the story of America, of women and men who defy the odds and never give up.
Now, that also links to a story that she told us on News & Notes.
Right before the South Carolina primary, a heavily black state, which Obama won decisively turned at least part of the tide.

And she said to us that her mother essentially would have been put in the foster care system if it was a different time, and she talked about how her mother was essentially abandoned at the age of eight, then moved on to be a domestic servant at the age of 14.
And how, although she - meaning Hillary Rodham Clinton, was comfortable, she could identify with this woman who lifted herself directly out of a path to lack of self-fulfillment.
And so I think that she has some stories that perhaps she did not tell enough to a wider audience.
Farai Chideya, thanks very much for your time today.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
And have fun at the convention.
I will.
Farai Chideya, the host of NPR's News & Notes.
She's with us today from NPR's headquarters at the Democratic National Convention in Denver.
We're talking about reaction to Hillary Clinton's speech last night and what her campaign meant for women's rights and for feminism.
800-989-8255 is our phone number.
Email us talk@npr.org.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
We're broadcasting today live from the Knight Studio inside the Newseum in Washington, D.C.
Sometime later today, the Democratic National Convention will formally nominate Barack Obama as the Democratic nominee for president.
That will mean the end of Senator Hillary Clinton's campaign, and it will be a difficult moment for many of the women who support her.
What did Senator Clinton's candidacy mean for women's rights and feminism?
Email us talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation and we'll be getting comments from members of our audience here at the Newseum as well.
Joining us now is Susan Faludi, a Pulitzer Prize and National Book Critics Circle award-winning journalist and author.
Her recent op-ed in the New York Times is titled ""Second-Place Citizens,"" and she joins us now from the studios of member station KQED in San Francisco.
And nice to have you on Talk of the Nation today.
Great to be here.
Thank you.
And we were talking about reaction from delegates on the floor with Farai Chideya just a moment ago.
Did that same message, do you think, get out beyond Denver?

Well, I'm not a pollster, so - and one of the things that struck me and was very frustrating in watching the coverage last night was, at least on the TV networks, there wasn't a whole lot of reporters running around asking people.
They were mostly talking to each other.
So I think, you know, time will tell.
But I certainly thought it was - I mean, I can't imagine a more gracious passing of the baton.
We talked - we get calls from some Obama supporters who say they can't understand why it's so difficult for some Hillary Clinton supporters to get over this.
Could you put this in some historical context for us?
Yes.
Well, you know - I mean, first of all, obviously saying I'm going to take my ball and go home or worse, saying I'm going to vote for McCain doesn't make a whole lot of sense.

But where that's coming from is a deep well of anger, and that anger is not so much related to Obama versus Clinton as it is to a much longer history of women's struggle in this country where they seem to be close to breaking through, seem to be on the verge of that meaningful transformational change, only be to be knocked back.
And ironically, the best example of this is suffrage.
Ironic, since Hillary Clinton was speaking on the 88th anniversary of suffrage's certification, as she pointed out.
And women's suffrage was supposed to be the big breakthrough.
And yet, in the years to follow, it was pretty much of a collapse on every front.
The women's voting bloc didn't emerge.
Women were not able to break into the political parties.
Very few women were able to get into higher office.
The sort of symbol of it all was probably Rebecca Felton, an 87-year-old woman from Georgia who was allowed to warm the seat of a new senator for one day.
That was how long her tenure in the Capitol lasted.
And on many other fronts.
Economically, in the professions, in the media, women were set back in the years to come.
And as we know, the next wave of feminism wasn't until the end of the 1960s.
As you wrote in the Times, every time it seemed to come up - women at least you have the perception of being told hey, wait your turn.
It's the old ""Wizard of Oz"" moment, where Dorothy is told go away and come back tomorrow.

And the women who are - it's particularly older women who are Hillary Clinton supporters have had a lifetime of this, of being told, you know, your issues aren't important, you're complaining about silly things.
This is trivial.
And these are women who have struggled their whole life and have come from a period pre-feminism and know how bad things can get when they slip back.
And on many fronts, and very much unacknowledged in the press, women are slipping back.
Economically, women's earnings have dropped for the last four consecutive years.
Women in political leadership is still - we're still at the bottom of the heap compared to other developed countries.
And women in fields from journalism to computer science to directing Hollywood movies to management have seen their progress either stall out or actually erode.
Let's get a question from here in the audience at the Newseum.
Hi, I'm Rachel and I live in Washington, D.C.
Last night, Hillary Clinton opened her speech by stating she's a proud mother.
Michelle Obama also made references to being a mother.
And I'm wondering, have we not moved beyond the point where a woman politician has to be a wife and mother first, and then she can be a politician?

Well, I think in Hillary Clinton's case, since she was introduced by her daughter, it seemed appropriate, and she did move on immediately to say, I'm a proud Democrat, I'm a proud this, you know, proud in the political arena, and ended it by saying, you know, I'm proud to be an Obama supporter.
For Michelle Obama she, you know, she had an assignment, a task ahead of her, which was to present herself as not a quote, unquote, ""angry woman,"" because that's how the media had presented her.
And she was - you know, her mission was to soften her image.

And that said, I thought it was really unfortunate that she had to talk so much about being a mom and a wife and a sister, you know, all of these - and sort of assuring the public that she had no aspirations and no anger.
And what's wrong with being angry?
We all should be very angry with what has happened in this country in the last eight years.
Let's get a caller on the line.
Kelly joins us, Kelly with us from Placerville in California.
Yes, hi.
I want to say that I think identifying Hillary Clinton as a feminist is a bit overblown from my point of view.
Because I feel that the majority of her work in her life was promoting Bill's career.
You know, when she could have been working on her own.
I mean, he was the one who ran for office.
He was the one who became president, governor and president, and so forth.
You know, I also think we need to pay homage to the women who really broke ground before Hillary Clinton.
I mean, there was Pat Schroeder who made, you know, a valiant effort toward presidency in the '70s.
There was Shirley Chisholm and Patsy Mink who, you know, weren't taken seriously but should have been.
I mean, they were really valid candidates, you know.

And now to speak of her as if she's a feminist - I know she, you know, hung out in the feminist circles in Washington, D.C., but to - you know, for me, I just see her as somebody who worked her way up through her husband.
And I don't really consider that so much of a feminist, something that feminists should necessarily applaud.
Susan Faludi, what do you think?
Well, you know, I agree that she's hardly presented herself as a fire-breathing feminist, or the stereotype of the quote, unquote, ""rabid feminist,"" whatever that is.

But I think she's also a work in progress and that over - certainly over the course of the campaign when she was hit with a, you know, an avalanche of misogyny from the media and from her own, you know, political compatriots who told her to, you know, stand down and shut up, basically - that she has moved much in the direction of being vocal about women's rights.

And you know, it's - she has done work, a great deal of work, you know, starting with, in 1995, the conference on women in Beijing, where she gave a very moving speech calling for women's rights, economic development for women around the globe.
And she's worked very hard behind the scenes for that.

And she's worked hard to, you know, for all kinds of things that really matter to women like expanding Family Medical Leave Act, like work - you know, fighting workplace discrimination, like reproductive rights.
So, you know, she's not Margaret Thatcher and she's not Helen Reddy, but you know, you've got to work with what you have.
And you know, I think that over time she became a much more strongly committed advocate to women's rights.
Right.
But I mean, I don't see it as a blow for feminism or for women that she has - didn't achieve the, you know, nomination because...
Well, I don't - you know, I'm not presenting it as a blow for fem - I think feminism has had taken so many blows.
It's close to flat on its back by now anyway.
Yeah.

But that - there's a great symbolic significance to - that shouldn't be understated to having a first woman president, just as it's - there's a very important symbolic statement to having a first black president.
I mean, the crying shame of this election is that we have to choose, which is why I say bring back Shirley Chisholm.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Kelly, thanks very much for the call.
You're welcome.
Joining us now is Lizz Winstead.
She's a comedian, co-creator of ""The Daily Show"" and the host of ""Thinking and Drinking with Lizz Winstead."" She joins us from the studios at Audio Ruckus in Minneapolis.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Thanks for having me.
And I wondered what you thought of Hillary's speech last night?
And I would also take a one step further: in a culture that has - there's this hipster quality of disconnect where it's very cool to not care.
And so, you know, when it comes to that and I've just - I had this sort of interesting experience on my show a couple of weeks ago where - OK.
(Soundbite of music)
This has nothing to do with consciousness.
This has nothing to do with any type of information which is digested here by these cells because they have no input.
Carnival worker?
Well, I guess I felt like she - in listening to it, I felt like she was still on the stump.

It was, this is what I did, this what I did, this is what I did and so, I mean, I hope that she can convince the people who were her supporters that have joined these groups called Puma and these other groups, you know, this I'll vote for McCain, instead of Obama.
You know, I can - I hope for that.
I don't know if it's effective.

It's just - those people are puzzling to me, but you know, there's a group of women who are feminists who a lot of people don't talk about, and they're women - I'm 47 and they're women my age who have sons and daughters who are between 17 and 25, who look at her war vote as a very detrimental thing.
And when you look at the Hillary supporters who are of Hillary's age group and who came up through feminism with her age group, they don't have kids that could potentially have to go to a war.
And those women really look at Hillary as selling out feminism and selling out their kid's futures, I think.
So, a slight generational divide, yet at one point in her speech clearly, Hillary Clinton did make a direct appeal - it seemed to me, anyway, to somewhat younger women.
Let's listen to this cut.
To my supporters, to my champions, to my sisterhood of the traveling pantsuits.
(Soundbite of cheering)
From the bottom of my heart, thank you.
And Lizz Winstead, as a professional - that's a pretty good line.
It is a pretty good line.
Although, I would like to see an end to the traveling pantsuit, in fact, I would like to see an end to the pantsuit, personally.
